comments.html: As a freelance networking consultant who works in multiple large enterprises, 2 words : "Wishful Thinking". The network will always be the duct tape to compensate for crappy application and enterprise architecture design.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: I have to agree with previous comment, application owners or developers consider networking an after thought. They don't consider distributed architecture, fail over situations, integrating with load balancers, they are rarely concerned about how it all works.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: I have yet to work with a development team that remotely understands networking let alone any of the more advanced topics mentioned above.  It feels like half my time is spent bending the network to the application.  The people above me don't care how it's done, just make it work.  I think this mentality is what keeps a lot of us employed.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: ... which is why I always claim that "making the developer answer the call when the application is down at 2AM on a Sunday morning miraculously reduces the number of bugs" (aka DevOps ;).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
This is because nobody is forcing them to take all the constraints into account. They live in their own world, doing their own magic and most of the time it is not in touch with real world.
However, at the end of the day they are not the ones doing the implementation and integration.
comments.name: Ales Travnikar
